chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Diaphragms and caps
chapter.summary: Covers advice on using diaphragms and caps, their advantages, disadvantages, and efficacy in preventing pregnancy.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years to 60 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What types of diaphragms and caps are available?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Diaphragms
  • Two types of diaphragm are available on prescription:
    • Silicone-based
      • Coiled spring diaphragm; type B. Sizes range from 60—90 mm in increments of 5 mm. 
      • Arcing spring diaphragm; type C. Sizes range from 60—90 mm in increments of 5 mm. They are useful for women with poor vaginal muscular support, or those in whom the length or position of the cervix makes fitting a coil spring diaphragm more difficult. 

Cervical caps

  • These are smaller than diaphragms and are a useful alternative for women who do not want to (or cannot) use a diaphragm. They are available in sizes 22, 26, and 30 mm. 
  • For information on assessing a woman prior to fitting a diaphragm or cap, see the section on How should I assess a woman who is considering using barrier methods and spermicides? in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.fullItemName: How diaphragms and cervical caps work
subChapters.htmlHeader: How do diaphragms and cervical caps work?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Diaphragms consist of a thin, soft dome (made of latex/rubber or silicone) with an encased flexible steel ring around its edge.
    • They are designed to fit between the posterior fornix of the vagina and the pubic bone. The diaphragm is held in place by the vaginal muscles, the tension of the ring, and the pubic bone.
  • Cervical caps fit directly over the cervix and are held in place by suction and by support from the vaginal wall.
  • When inserted correctly, the diaphragm and cap fit into the vagina to cover the cervix, thus excluding semen.
  • They are used in conjunction with a spermicide, which further reduces the likelihood of fertilization.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a], the Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Of Canada (SOGC) guideline Canadian contraception consensus. Part 2 [SOGC, 2015], and the Family Planning Association Handbook of sexual health in primary care [Hatcher, 2011].

  • The information on the available types of diaphragms and caps is taken from the British National Formulary [BNF 71, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman prior to fitting a diaphragm or cap?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • For information on assessing a woman prior to fitting a diaphragm or cap, see the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Are there any medical conditions for which diaphragms and caps are unsuitable?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Caps and diaphragms should generally be avoided in women with the following conditions:
    • High risk of HIV or infected with HIV. 
    • History of toxic shock syndrome. 
    • Latex sensitivity (silicone diaphragms and cervical caps can be used).
  • Postpartum and parous women
    • Diaphragms are unsuitable for women who are less than 6 weeks postpartum. 
    • A different size of diaphragm or cap may be required by women who used this method prior to pregnancy.
    • The failure rates of cervical caps may be higher for parous women.
  • In addition:
    • The diaphragm cannot be used in certain cases of vulvovaginal prolapse.
    • The cap is not appropriate for a woman with a markedly distorted cervical anatomy.
    • The cap should not be used in women with cervical cancer or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. There is no restriction for diaphragm use.
      • Repeated and high-dose use of the spermicide nonoxynol-9 can cause vaginal and cervical irritation or abrasions.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a].

HIV
  • There is evidence that use of the spermicide nonoxynol-9 is associated with the development of genital lesions, which may increase the risk of acquiring or transmitting HIV.

subChapters.fullItemName: How diaphragms and cervical caps are fitted
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should diaphragms and cervical caps be fitted?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Diaphragms and caps should initially be fitted by a trained and competent healthcare professional.
  • Initially the diaphragm or cap should be used together with another method (for example condoms) until the woman is confident that she can use it correctly.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a].

subChapters.fullItemName: How to use a diaphragm or cervical cap
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should diaphragms or cervical caps be used?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Prior to use, advise the woman to:
    • Check for any holes or deterioration in the diaphragm or cap before insertion.
    • Apply a spermicide to the diaphragm or cap.
      • Apply approximately two 2 cm strips of spermicide to the upper surface of the diaphragm. Some spermicide can be applied to the leading edge of the rim to ease insertion.
      • When using a cap, fill about a third of the inside of the cap with spermicide. Spermicide should not be put on the rim of a cervical cap.
    • Keep oil-based products (such as baby oil, some topical corticosteroids, and oestrogen preparations) out of contact, as they can cause damage to latex diaphragms and caps.
  • To use diaphragms and caps, advise the woman that:
    • The diaphragm or cervical cap can be inserted up to 3 hours before sexual intercourse, and must be left in situ for at least 6 hours after the last episode of sexual intercourse — sperm in the lower reproductive tract are unlikely to survive after 6 hours. 
    • Diaphragms should be removed within 30 hours of insertion and caps within 48 hours.
    • Additional spermicide should be applied (using an applicator) without removing the diaphragm or cervical cap if sexual intercourse is repeated, or the diaphragm or cap has been in situ for 3 hours or more before sexual intercourse takes place. 
  • After intercourse, advise the woman to:
    • Wash the diaphragm or cap with mild unscented soap, rinse well, and dry carefully before storing in a cool place.
  • If the diaphragm or cap is incorrectly inserted, damaged, dislodged, or removed within 6 hours of sexual intercourse:
    • Consider the possibility of pregnancy and whether emergency contraception is appropriate. For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a] and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics for Gygel® Contraceptive Jelly [ABPI, 2014].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I follow up a woman after a diaphragm or cervical cap has been fitted?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Reassess the woman after 1–2 weeks; review the device's fit and the woman's skills in using it.
    • Ask:
      • If she is comfortable while using the method for the duration of its use, including during intercourse.
      • If she is able to tolerate keeping it in overnight if sex occurs in the evening.
      • If there is any intolerance or adverse effects to the use of spermicide.
    • Ensure that the woman is able to check the position of the diaphragm or cervical cap before and after intercourse, and recognize if it is correctly positioned.
    • Remind the woman that:
      • When inserted correctly, neither partner should be able to feel the diaphragm or cap. If the diaphragm or cap can be felt or is uncomfortable, the woman should return to reassess fit, or to consider an alternative diaphragm or cap, or another method of contraception.
      • The diaphragm or cap should be replaced immediately if there are any holes or puckering. Discolouration with use is normal; the latex is unaffected.
    • Advise the woman that the fit of the diaphragm or cap should be rechecked by a trained healthcare professional, after childbirth, termination of pregnancy, miscarriage, and if she experiences significant weight gain or loss (3 kg or more), because the vagina and cervix can change shape or size.
      • Women are advised to wait 6 weeks after delivery before using the diaphragm or cervical cap, to allow the uterus to return to its pre-pregnancy size and condition.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a] and expert opinion in a medical textbook [Guillebaud, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the advantages and disadvantages of using diaphragms or cervical caps?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advantages

  • Adverse effects are rare.
  • They can be inserted at a convenient time (up to 3 hours) before intercourse, so that spontaneity can be maintained.
  • The woman can control the use of contraception.
  • These methods are not compromised by concurrent drug therapy (for example liver enzyme-inducing drugs).

Disadvantages

  • Effectiveness is low compared with hormonal and intrauterine methods.
  • Failure rates for cervical caps (but not diaphragms) may be increased for parous women.
  • They require motivation and careful use on each occasion to be effective.
  • They require planning so that the diaphragm or cap is in place or readily available.
  • The diaphragm or cap must be left in place for at least 6 hours after sexual intercourse.
  • They cannot be used until 6 weeks post-partum or 6 weeks following second trimester termination.
  • The fit needs to be rechecked after weight gain or loss of 3 kg or more, and after giving birth.
  • Some women may be allergic to the material from which the diaphragm is made.
  • The incidence of urinary tract infection may be increased in some women who use diaphragms — this often relates to the fit and size of the diaphragm, which may put pressure on the urethra.
  • They may not reduce the risk of transmission of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
  • They must be used with spermicide, which may cause irritation or allergy.
  • They should not be used by women at high risk of STIs, as spermicides can increase the risk of infection.
  • Some women find the method messy to use.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a], the Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Of Canada (SOGC) guideline Canadian contraception consensus. Part 2 [SOGC, 2015], and the Family Planning Association Handbook of sexual health in primary care [Hatcher, 2011].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How effective are diaphragms and caps at preventing pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For comparison of the efficacy of diaphragms and caps with other methods of contraception, see the section on How effective are the available contraceptive methods? in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

Diaphragm plus spermicide

  • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly), 6% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure.
  • When used typically, 12% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure or user failure.

Cervical cap plus spermicide

  • Parous women:
    • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly), 20% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure.
    • When used typically, 24% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure or user failure.
  • Nulliparous women:
    • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly), 9% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure.
    • When used typically, 12% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure or user failure.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Barrier methods for contraception and STI prevention [FSRH, 2015a] and expert opinion in the medical textbook Contraceptive technology [Hatcher, 2011].
